results.headline: Review: In ‘Something Better to Come,’ Growing Up in a Garbage Dump
results.summary_short: Hanna Polak’s documentary visits Yula and the rest of a community squatting for years in a landfill outside wealthy Moscow.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Something Better to Come

results.headline: Review: In ‘Human Centipede 3’ There’s No Humanity Left
results.summary_short: The film, subtitled “Final Sequence,” feels drained and desperate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Human Centipede 3: Final Sequence

results.headline: Review: ‘Aloft’ Trains an Eagle Eye on Human Misery
results.summary_short: Claudia Llosa’s movie concerns a healer, her two sons and the ambivalence she feels about her gift.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aloft

results.headline: Review: ‘The Japanese Dog,’ a Family Reunion in Romania
results.summary_short: In Tudor Cristian Jurgiu’s first feature film, a Romanian engineer living in Japan takes his family to visit his father, a curmudgeonly widower who has lost everything.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Japanese Dog

results.headline: Review: ‘Güeros’ Amid the Mexican Student Protests of 1999
results.summary_short: In Alonso Ruizpalacios’s film, a boy from the country arrives in Mexico City just in time for the student strikes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Güeros

results.headline: Review: ‘Bombay Velvet’ Is a Bollywood Ode to American Gangster Movies
results.summary_short: Anurag Kashyap’s movie about an evolving Bombay shows evidence of a changing Indian film scene.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bombay Velvet

results.headline: Review: ‘Mad Max: Fury Road,’ Still Angry After All These Years
results.summary_short: This George Miller film, with Tom Hardy as the hero, has the spirit of a sequel to the original: Speed and efficiency are of the essence, leavened with nasty biker wit and distaste for authority.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mad Max: Fury Road

results.headline: Review: ‘Good Kill’ Stars Ethan Hawke Fighting Enemies Half a World Away
results.summary_short: This Andrew Niccol film is a blunt critique of remote-control warfare, which is transforming the reality of battle into a video game whose casualties are pixels on a screen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Kill

results.headline: ‘Every Secret Thing,’ an Unsettling Story of When Babies Go Missing
results.summary_short: This movie stars Dakota Fanning and Danielle Macdonald as teenagers who committed a crime as young girls, and who are suspected of being repeat offenders.

results.headline: Review: ‘Where Hope Grows,’ a Baseball Career Lost and Relationships Found
results.summary_short: Chris Dowling’s film begins with a clichéd character, the failed athlete with a drinking problem, and features a young man with Down syndrome in his first acting role.

results.headline: Review: ‘Slow West,’ a Wry Twist on Classic Frontier Fables
results.summary_short: John Maclean’s film plants a hapless innocent in a land of pitiless outlaws.

results.headline: Review: ‘Pitch Perfect 2,’ With Anna Kendrick and More Fat Amy
results.summary_short: This sequel pits the Barden Bellas, the all-girl a cappella group, against some highly disciplined German singers, and gives Fat Amy a solo.

results.headline: Review: ‘Our Man in Tehran’ Recounts Iran Hostage Crisis Escape
results.summary_short: The tale of how the Canadian ambassador and others helped six American Embassy workers escape Iran in 1980 makes a watchable documentary.

results.headline: Review: ‘L for Leisure,’ Vignettes of Graduate Students on Vacation
results.summary_short: Set in the early 1990s, this experimental comedy from Lev Kalman and Whitney Horn offers ample opportunities to watch ostensibly smart people behaving stupidly.

results.headline: Review: ‘In the Name of My Daughter,’ a Family-Business Scandal

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Film Critic,’ a Snob Is Tripped Up by His Heartstrings

results.summary_short: The film presents stories drawn from the life experiences of its fledgling actors.

results.headline: Review: In ‘I’ll See You in My Dreams,’ Blythe Danner Seeks Fulfillment

results.headline: Review: In ‘Animals,’ a Couple in Love With Heroin
results.summary_short: A college-educated, middle-class couple create a self-contained civilization in which heroin is a powerful force within their personal love story.
